title.narrative: Stöd till Mercy Corps PROSPECTS II
Support to PROSPECTS II, Mercy Corps

description.narrative: Increase youth's business skills and vocational aptitude through apprenticeships and business skills training. Sport clubs and cash-for work activities for the most vulnerable groups. Phase II.
Öka ungdomars affärskunskaper och relaterade färdigheter genom lärlingsprogram och utbildning i näringsidkande. Sport och kontanter-för-arbete till de mest utsatta i gruppen. Fas II.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The Prospects program has five pillars (psychosocial, employment and entrepreneurship, new day innovations for youth employment, results, learning and research, and partnership). Each of these pillars has shown significant results during the reporting period (7 July 2016 through 6 January 2017). Prospects reached 12,366 unique youth through a range of services that support young Liberians as they seek meaningful, market-driven employment or self-employment.
The Psycho-social sub-program has engaged over 3,515 vulnerable young Liberians in 138 self-help groups that promoted improved livelihoods through enhanced community and market integration. Working through partner organizations, Prospects provided the tools for each group to start a Village Savings and Loan Association (VSLA). The young men and women that benefited from the VSLA reported that the loans have helped them to create new revenue streams, pursue educational opportunities and support their families. Endline survey showed the percentage of youth earning revenue from VSLA (group business) increased from 3% at the start of the program to 25% at the end of the program. One of the groups that benefited, the 'Successful Girls of VOA' indicated that revenue from the VSLA contributed to building their livelihood and their family wellbeing.
The Employment and Entrepreneurship (E&E) sub- program reached 8,553 young people, engaging them in work readiness and business skills trainings. Prospects continued to connect young people to employment opportunities through three-month apprenticeships with local businesses. 701 young people have completed apprenticeships (with 48 percent offered full-time employment upon completion of their placement). Prospects offered business start-up grants upon submission and approval of written business plans to young entrepreneurs. 602 business start-up grants were disbursed with individual monitoring and mentoring support from the Prospects team.
The New Day sub-program awarded business grant to Jet-Del; a housekeeping and janitorial services company. With business advisory and financial support, Jet-Del created 27 new employment positions for 23 young women and four young men. Prospects continued its engagement with Tamma Corporation, an information technology company that is addressing labor market failures by improving youth access to information about employment opportunities and vocational paths.
Prospects produced ten learning and research papers that focused on several themes including on factors motivating young female entrepreneurship, and on financial behavior & financial services market segmentation of youth & young entrepreneurs in Liberia. Another study investigated youth interaction with and perceptions of the agriculture sector. The study found that despite the common notion that youth are uninterested in agriculture, Liberian youth see it as an important economic sector that provides a viable way of constructing a livelihood and building respect in their communities. The study found that youth have limited knowledge about food systems and value chains, and are unaware of opportunities for non-traditional engagement in the sector. Learnings from these studies will be incorporated into future programing to promote youth in the agriculture sector.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
